STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 8, 2021
Michelle Carlton
Child Safe Michigan Judson CS
4410 West 13 Mile Road
Royal Oak, MI 48073
RE: License #: CB630369213
Child Safe Michigan Judson CS
4410 West 13 Mile Road
Royal Oak, MI 48073
Dear Ms. Carlton:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
May 24, 2021 to June 4, 2021. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, explain why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact my area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Alicia Wiggins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 917-1048
enclosure
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the
report.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services
worker that has children placed in the home.
(5)(d) In one out of three special evaluation records reviewed, the last names of the
children who were interviewed were included in the report.
(6)(c) In one out of three special evaluation records reviewed, there was no
documentation that a copy of the report was provided to the social services worker
that had children placed in the home.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the updated service plans
(USPs) were not completed timely.
 For one record, the USP was due on December 16, 2020 and it was
completed on December 18, 2020.
 For one record, the USP was due on January 15, 2021 and it was completed
on January 20, 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 11, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2020 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 31, 2020.
4

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes.
FOM 722-06B
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home
cases:
• Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before
the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting (FTM)
Report, must be completed for every FTM.
In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, FTMs were not completed
timely.
 For one record, a FTM for case service plan development for the USP ending
on October 4, 2020 was not completed within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
 For one record, FTMs for case service plan development for the USPs ending
on August 26, 2020 and on May 21, 2021 were not completed within 30
calendar days before the case plan due dates.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2020 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 31, 2020.
DHHS Policy Timely Entry of Case Contacts.
FOM 722-06H
All caseworker contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS; this
includes attempted contacts and missed appointments, and
all pertinent information obtained must be summarized and
included in the appropriate section of the case service plan.
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS,
within five business days of the contact. This includes the
following:
•Any face-to-face contacts with children, parents, or
caregivers made by any of the following:
 Foster care worker.
5

 CPS worker.
 Adoption worker.
 Permanency resource monitors.
 Parent/child face-to-face contacts.
 Sibling/child face-to face contacts.
In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, all contacts were not entered
in MiSACWIS within five business days of the contact.
 For one record, the sibling visit for December 2020 was completed on
December 9, 2020 and it was entered in MiSACWIS on June 4, 2021.
 For one record, the May2021 face-to-face contact with the foster child and the
caregiver was completed on May 17, 2021 and it was entered in MiSACWIS
on June 2, 2021.
DHHS Policy Maintaining Connections through Visitation and Contact:
FOM 722-06I Sibling Visitation and Ongoing Interaction.
Siblings in foster care, who are not placed together, must
have at least one visit per calendar month that is in addition
to parenting time.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, which required sibling visits,
there was no documentation that a sibling visit occurred in September 2020.
DHHS Policy Foster Care – Updated Service Plan (Supervisory
FOM 722-09 Approval).
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within fourteen calendar
days of the report date.
6

In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the USPs were not approved
by the supervisor within fourteen calendar days of the report date.
 For one record, one report was completed on September 17, 2020 and it was
approved on October 8, 2020. Another report was completed on December
18, 2020 and it was approved on January 13, 2021.
 For one record, one report was completed on May 11, 2021 and it was
approved on May 27, 2021.
 For one record, one report was completed on August 26, 2020 and it was
approved on September 21, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 11, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2020 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 31, 2020.
DHHS Policy Health Requirements- Periodicity Schedule.
FOM 801
After the initial medical examination upon entering foster
care, all children require an EPSDT/well child exam
according to the periodicity schedule recommended by the
American Academy of Pediatrics.
•For children under 3 years old, the periodicity schedule for
EPSDT/well child exams is as follows:
Newborn - 1 week of age.
4 weeks of age.
2 months of age.
4 months of age.
6 months of age.
9 months of age.
12 months of age.
15 months of age.
18 months of age.
24 months of age.
30 months of age.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, which was under the age of
three years old, the fifteen months well child exam was due by May 15, 2021 and it
was not completed.
DHHS Policy Personnel Training.
SRM 200
All personnel, contractors, vendors and external auditors
who have access to CW-CHRI are required to complete
security awareness training (SAT). Training will be available
on the Learning Management System (LMS) for MDHHS
personnel and contractors with access to this system.
7

SAT is required to be taken within six months of being in a
position with CW-CHRI access and every two years
thereafter.
There were thirteen employees who were required to complete SAT since the last
inspection. Based on a review of LMS transcripts for employees, who have access
and have had access to CW-CHRI since the last inspection, one employee was
found to have not completed SAT timely. The training was due by February 8, 2021
and it was completed on February 9, 2021.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
One CAP was in response to the 2020 Interim Inspection findings.
During the inspection entrance meeting, the chief administrator discussed her
findings, which were consistent with the findings of the inspection.
The staff and supervisors interviewed reported no concerns with the program. They
indicated that at times it has been a challenge to attend virtual trainings and
meetings. The staff reported they are passionate about ensuring that the children
and families they serve receive the services that they need. This was reflected in the
inspection results.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend that the facility
8

will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
June 7, 2021
________________________________________
Alicia Wiggins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 8, 2021
________________________________________

Area Manager
